text: Okay? Okay. You got the tape going? The tape is rolling. Okay. What I've done, Mr. Knight, is simply to, as I said, you've done so much. You've been so involved in the field that it was hard to get a handle on how to approach this. But what I've done is sort of divide up into different areas, and I'll ask you some brief questions on each one. And the first one would involve your entry into science fiction. You came through the fan structure, and I wondered if you could explain how you were introduced to that. I sort of thought that might come up, and I was rooting about it a little yesterday. Actually, I was thinking, what if you asked me to where I would contribute my gigantic success? I would have to say mostly luck. I can trace my career back through a series of just astounding coincidences, really unlikely things, all the way back to Hulu Gernsback. And I can demonstrate that at each of these points, If something rather unlikely had not happened, I wouldn't be doing what I'm doing. For instance, if Hugo Gernsback had not come to this country from Luxembourg when he was 14 and started a magazine called Amazing Stories in 1926, you'll see as I go on that none of the other things could have happened. So here I am, a 13-year-old kid in Hood River, Oregon, reading science fiction magazines, really turned on by them. and through the back pages of one of these magazines super science stories then edited by Frederick Bull I found out about the fanzines and rode away for a few and this way got into correspondence with the Futurians including then Bull and Walheim and Cyril Kornblitz and a bunch of others Robert Dudley Lowndes I was trying to write some stories and I sent a couple to Lowndes, who was then acting as a sort of half-assed literary agent. And all these things added up together until Donald A. Walheim got an offer from a publisher to edit a new science fiction magazine. He had no budget, whatever, for stories. And he knew about me from Lowndes. Lowndes wrote to me saying, will you donate this story to the first issue of Superstirring Science Story? And of course I said yes. I would have paid for the privilege. And as a consequence of that, the Futurians invited me to come and be a Futurian, live in one of their communal dwellings in New York when I was 18. Terribly unlikely thing, just a series of them, even as far as we've gone. And I lived there a couple of years doing little illustrations from magazines and trying to write. Not deceiving very much. And then in 1943, Again, it was Fred Pulle, got me a job at popular publications where he was working. I needed an assistant editor, and he knew I would work cheap. So he got me an interview where I got the job. Spent about a year there, and I'm perfectly convinced now, looking back, that it was that training at popular publications that enabled me to write fiction professionally. It was a training that you couldn't get in any school. How did you get it now? But it just kind of soaked in because I was reading the slush pile, the unsolicited manuscripts, and it became perfectly obvious after a while what the difference was between the stuff we were rejecting and the stuff we were printing. So when I quit that job, I started writing and went on from there. I did another stint later at Popular, 1949. And I also worked for a while at the Scott Merritt's Literary Agency, which was a reading fee agency, where we would get these awful manuscripts and have to criticize them. I think that helped me a good deal, too. If I could recommend the writing, or the training for young writers, I would certainly say it's too bad that those pulp magazines don't exist anymore. You can possibly get an editorial job or anything of that kind. Even a terrible job in the reading fee literary agency. Okay. Okay, we talked to Frederick Pohl some time ago and he told us a little about the Futurians and of course you've written a book on that too Could you be a little more specific, sort of briefly what your relationship with the Futurians was what exactly they did? Well, the Futurians were a very informal organization of science fiction bands who were trying to become professional and in some cases had a little bit of impact of success here and there, published stories. I told you that Walheim was editing a magazine. Before him, Poe had become an editor. After him, Lowndes also became an editor. They were writing and publishing a little bit, not much. To save money, because they were all very poor, they lived in a communal apartment. At that time in New York, in the late 30s and early 40s, There were lots of apartments among them that were very cheap. I forget now. I think the rental might have been about 30 bucks for a four-bedroom railroad flat. If you had four people living there, it was quite cheap. And we divided up the household duties around with the cooking. And I did the fish washing, which I hated. We were dirtboard. We really didn't have any money at all. We rolled our own cigarettes, and we bought the cheapest wine we could find, which was something like 85 cents a gallon. Our major entertainment was walking down from 102nd Street, or 103rd, it was, down to Times Square, and looking at the bright lights and having a cup of coffee in the cafeteria and then walking home. I read once where your actually your first professional sale was a cartoon is that right I suppose that's right I hadn't thought about that it was a cartoon that I sent to Amazing Stories which was before I went to New York before I told a story I must have been 17 I sent some other ones and I didn't like them okay your your if I'm correct here your earliest work in the fanzines was of a critical nature and I wondered if that's true why you started out with did you just have a critical bent or did you not want to write creatively at first I was trying to write fiction at that time and not succeeding I couldn't finish stories I didn't have any idea of how you got to the end of the story but I was extremely critical and starting like any other right 17 or 18 year old fan The first stuff I did for fanzines was not critical in the usual sense. I mean, it wasn't book-reviewed or that kind of thing, but it was parody mostly. The things that I thought were really outstandingly dumb in the magazine, funny enough to parody, and I did a lot of that. But when I say a lot, I lie, because I only published two issues of my fanzines and did very little for other magazines. It was much later, sorry, about 1945, I think. I did a long critical essay about Van Gogh for one of Larry Shaw's amateur magazines. That was really the first critical work in the usual chemical I did. From what I've read of your, say, your collected essays and so forth, the things that you've done in terms of criticism, I would say that probably your major concern overall has been to deal with the question of science fiction as a higher, to raise its literary standards perhaps, to make it something more than just a kind of a second class kind of literature. And I wondered if you thought that science fiction could ever compete with mainstream and characterization, human relations, and so forth, or is it too limited to do that? Well, that was my position, And I didn't see any reason why science fiction shouldn't be as good as any other kind of fiction can be. I don't think now that it ever has been. And I still have, and I have a few doubts now about whether it can be. But at that time, as you say, my effort was to try to raise the standards, improve the breed, mainly by shooting cripples. you maybe have some doubts now whether science fiction could ever produce somebody like say a Dostoevsky then yeah of course mainstream hasn't produced another Dostoevsky either so these comparisons are really not much help but in the 50s there was a really strong invigorating movement to upgrade science fiction in certain ways by lifting it out of the Pope formulas. H.L. Gould was responsible for part of that and Tony Boucher for another part, and it really seemed to me that we were on a plateau which could quite well be succeeded by another plateau and so on, upward. And I think that was what I was pushing for. I haven't seen it happen. We have some very good work being done, very literary work, But it doesn't seem to me that the field as a whole has advanced as much as I expected it would beyond the 1950s. Would you see any big changes in the field since you began? Oh, muchos. I started reading in 1933 and picked up all the back issues I could find in second-hand bookstores in Portland. and the situation in the 30s was a little fragmented. By that time, Gernsback had lost his magazines, and he didn't have Gernsback in SF anymore. His idea was to teach science through science fiction. He didn't always do it, but that was his ideal. And then you had his successor at Amazing Stories, Tio Connor Sloan, who was then in his 80s. I never met him, but he was described as a marvelous, white-bearded old gentleman who considered science fiction a sort of a hobby. What he liked was archaeology. And he really did not have any of the technocratic fervor that Gernsback has. In fact, he said in print more than once that he didn't believe that space travel would ever happen. And then you had astounding stories which in the early 30s was strictly a rather low grade adventure magazine their contribution to the field was to import the stereotypes of adventure fiction which worked very well and we still see that thread running through science fiction right up to the present time and then in the late 30s 37, 38 John Campbell took over astounding and more or less transformed it he raised the level in a certain direction he wanted scientific accuracy or at least a semblance of it lack of scientific ignorance he wanted plausible stories about the future not the usual triad of a brave hero and his jodhors and amen, and the fainting heroine and the mad scientist. So in that sense, and also because he got a, um, stable of very good writers in the early 40s, that raised the level considerably, markedly. And then as I say, Gold and Boucher and others came along in the 50s, and there was another quantum leap. And it seemed to me that that was the natural course of the dance. What we wanted was another quantum leap. so on until there would be no distinguishable difference in terms of quality between science fiction and mainstream. And as I say, I don't think that happens. Some of those quantum leaps in the past that you've mentioned have been due, I think, to, as you said, to some of the more influential editors. Do we have editors today who still have that kind of influence? Well, I think we have certainly influential editors, but I don't think they're trying to do that. I think they're trying to produce what they conceive the reading public wants and they're very successful at it. George Sithers, for example, is a very sharp editor. And Stanley Schmidt, I think, is doing an excellent job with analog. And of course Ed Furman has been working along with fantasy and science fiction for many years. Publishing a lot of really neat stuff. Fantasy and science fiction has always had a more literary cast. and the other magazines, partly because it's about half and half fantasy and science fiction, as the name would suggest. And for some reason, the literary quality of fantasy writing has tended to be higher than that in science fiction. Okay, listen, when you began your Orbit anthologies in 1966, what kind of hopes did you have for them? What was your idea behind them? Well, in the first place, I just thought there was a marketing strategy there that hadn't been explored. Please forgive my costs. It seemed to me that with hardcover publication, if you could get book club and paperback, you'd have a basis on which you could pay very good rates and get a broad audience. and that because it was hardcover, originally you wouldn't have to worry about some of the pulp cliches on the juvenile reader. And that didn't work either. Orbit never did achieve the sales that I hoped for or the publishers hoped for. It got a few book club sales but not many. It wasn't every issue, it should have been. And the paperback never did sell very well. So after they went to harbor with the series, they couldn't get paperback at all, and that was what made them cancel it after a while. They hung on quite a long time. They were very decent about it. But eventually they saw that this wasn't going to happen. Well, was that the first anthology of original science fiction that was published? No, it was not. Fred Poole had done a series called Star. Let me think. It must have been in the late 50s. I forget. and before him there had been a couple of one shot original anthologies I've forgotten who the editors were, let me think I used to I think the first one actually goes back quite a way it was something rather inconspicuous and nobody paid much attention but Fred was the first series of anthologies of original science fiction stories In terms of the I guess the literary level of the orbit series, so you must be proud of that through some of those years, that I think the majority of the Nebula Award stories came from orbit, didn't they? For a couple of years, it was scoring heavily in the nebulas, yeah. But I don't really know whether that has anything to do with the quality of the stories, or just because I was conspicuous at the time, I was the president of SFWA. Yeah, that leads me onto the next area I want to talk about. You had a large part in the founding of that. Could you explain your part in that and why you were interested in starting it? Well, about ten years earlier, it must have been, there was an effort to form a guild of science fiction writers, and I went to one or two of their meetings, and it was pitiful because they used the parliamentary procedure and they had 50 people all arguing, and they finally hammered out a set of bylaws and elected officers, and then nothing happened. The officers all went home and died. And I realized at that time that there was a very easy way to do it. You didn't have to have the big meetings, and you didn't have to have all that apparatus. One person could do it. But I didn't think I was conspicuous enough at that time. I didn't think anybody knew who I was. Later on, I was becoming more visible, and I realized that I probably could do it. the precipitating event was by receiving in the same week three requests for anthology reprints for flat fees, which I thought was unfair to the author. So I wrote a flyer, the one-page thing, advising authors not to sign agreements for flat fee anthology reprints, and saying, if you'd like more information of this kind, send in your three bucks and become a charter member of SFWA. So I got a flock of responses. When I had about 78, I declared them the charter members and wrote a set of bylaws and sent that around, and we were more or less in business. Okay, and what did you serve? One or two years as president? I did two terms. Okay, and you'd have to look back. Wouldn't you have to judge it today as a successful organization? I think so. I think it's done more for members than any other writer's organization that I know of. We got about 9,000 bucks in back royalties for Tolkien and lots of things for isn't that awful, her name just popped out of my head. Andrew Norton. And we've settled a lot of grievances. The latest one was a really terrible new contract which Davis Publications began to use. Just an awful contract. Gobbling up both. every right conceivably attached to a story, and we made such a stench that they withdrew it. About a year ago, we talked to Norman Spinrad, I guess, who's the current president, and he said he was interested in working on internationalizing or hooking up with some of the European organizations. Do you think that's a good idea? There's a lot of feeling among the members that we ought to be more international than we are. I always resisted that because it didn't seem to me that we could work effectively for writers living abroad and not publishing in this country. I guess it's harmless. I don't see that it could do us any damage. Okay, let me move on to one more area before I get down to just a few questions on your own work. I guess you realize I'll probably have to ask something about the Milford Science Fiction Writers Conference. Could you also give me a brief statement on the genesis of that? Well, this was in the mid-50s, and for some reason, Judy Merrill and I got talking about the idea of having a writer's conference in Milford, Pennsylvania, which is a very small town in the Poconos. It was sort of the way you might talk about building a boat in the basement, and nothing was done about this until Judy and I went to the World Con in Detroit, I think it was, and discovered that he was much more better than we realized. Well, that energized us, and we thought that possibly if we invited people to the military, they could actually come. And we sent out the invitation. We got Jim Wish to join the masthead, lend it more respectability, and this was the year in which the following year of New York, so it was easier for people to get out there directly afterwards. Then we got 40 people. Just amazing. It was quite intense. We had evening discussions that went on for several hours with people raising parts of hands to do the next to speak. Quite exciting. So we decided to do it annually. After the first one, we didn't have a World Con near us to provide all that many people. and the attendance dropped to, I don't know, 15 or so. When it gradually came up again, we began to get a bunch of regulars who came every year and then there'd be a few more and so on. So in the later years, we got up to about 25 or 30, which was really as much as we could handle in the workshops, which by then had become a regular feature of Milford, where everybody would submit a manuscript or two. And then every morning we'd all sit around having read these manuscripts and discuss them in turn around the surface. This is probably an obvious question, but I want to ask it anyhow to see your response. Do you think writers are, what kind of benefit, what kind of benefit would writers get from that? Have they been benefited? Well, this is a question that Katie and I ask ourselves every year because we teach at Clarion, which is an outgrowth of Milford. And you can certainly point to lists of distinguished ex-Milfordites and Marianites. It is a distinguished list. But whether that proves anything or not is another question. You have to have a control group which we have never had. I can testify that if you could help me in a specific way. the workshop helps. People point out what it was in your story that you absolutely haven't seen, sometimes crucially. And, again, just from my own experience, it seems to me that learning to criticize other people's stories technically enables you eventually to criticize your own, which is a difficult thing at all. It becomes a little bit easier to see the flaws in your own. okay you're not associated with the Milford conference anymore then no, we had to stop doing it five or six years ago don't hold me to the number because I'm very weak on dates it turned out that year that we had signed up for so many things in the summer that were going to have to drop something and it couldn't be clarion we were committed to that so we had to stop doing Milford and it wasn't really a a painful loss to us by that time because our old gang dispersed. We had moved away from Milford first to Florida and then to Oregon. And it just wasn't the same thing anymore. It was turning into more of a sort of mini clarion where you had the chiefs and the Indians. Katie and I were the chiefs and the rest were Indians which had not been the case at all at Milford. That was by design and practice. a group of peers. So that Milford, as it has turned out, has become sort of a duplication for us of what we were doing at Clarion. Ed Bryan has done it a couple of times, about every year, in Denver or thereabouts. And it is still going on. But the difference between the two, like you said, the Clarion would be more for actual beginners, where you would be the teacher rather than peers. Okay, let me just move on while we have some time to your own work because I have some questions on that I'm not sure what your intended titles were but the two novels A for Anything and Analog Men they're also known as The People Maker and Hell's Pavement what are the titles you prefer? Analog Men and Hell's Pavement were my titles they were retitled by paperback editors they used to do that a lot they don't do it for much anymore the Okay, the A for anything was called the people maker though wasn't it? No, it was first A for anything The first book publication was the paperback which was retitled by the paperback editor but I published portions of it in magazines and one of them had the title that I preferred A for anything I hate the title of the people maker Okay in that book The A for Anything I'm sure you've gotten questions on this in fact I know you have but the totally unexpected ending that comes up at least I as a reader expected the protagonist I forget his name right now to become sort of a good guy to overcome his training and to let the old slave live and to marry the woman and so forth why did you choose to have him revert to his stratified, slave-oriented society? Well, what you're talking about, the ending that you expected is the cliche ending, romantic and sentimental. I wanted to do a realistic ending. I thought that the happy ending to that, you know, a conventional, quote, happy ending to that novel would have been false. And this was one of the things that's interesting in writing the novel in the first place. You know, anything I've done, except for the slapstick. I was trying to do science fiction realistically. I thought that was part of the new wave. It wasn't called that then, but the wave of realism that came in the 50s. And I was awfully enthired, still I am, of the romantic cliches of science fiction. Okay, the device that you put into that novel, The Gizmo, The Transform Society, it's kind of ironic that a device like that which can give people whatever they want would lead to a slave master society do you think that's the way it would work or would you be being deliberately pessimistic? well, I thought it was logical I was counter-punching in that novel against some other treatments of the same device the same gadgets that had been published before which I thought were cop-outs. For instance, George Oak Smith wrote one in which the matter-to-date duplicator was invented, and of course chaos ensued, and he rescued the world by inventing a kind of currency that couldn't be duplicated. And that was one too many rabbits out of the hat, I thought. So, again, I just wanted to do it realistically. It seemed to me that if I had made a good case that, in fact, slavery would be the No, I admit that it was an imaginative projection. I don't necessarily defend the idea that that's what would happen in practice. And another writer, several years later, I'll think of his name if I possibly can, wrote a story in response to that one, which really delighted me. I like this dialogue aspect of science fiction, in which he showed that a good marketer, a good businessman, could get along perfectly well and make money, even if there was a matter duplicative. Marvelous story. When A for Anything and Analog Men, when those were published in the 50s, there wasn't much critical science fiction. Was there maybe, things like The Space Merchants, your books remind me of, We are criticizing a consumer-oriented society. There wasn't much of that those days, was there? No, I think Fred Gould and Ezele Cure was the space merchant's gravy planet, it was called and it was published in the magazine, was a stunning rejection of the kind of dramatic cliché that has been dominant in science fiction up to a new time. There had been social satire in science fiction for a long time before, during science fiction. And the magazine published some of it, but it was pretty remote. It didn't have the cutting edge that gravy plan it had. Okay, maybe just one question on Analog Man. I think that you're contrasting the scientist, Cusco or Cusco, whatever his name is, who invents, of course, the device which causes the analog and leads to the kind of society they have in Laudermilk, the more humanitarian type. But in their own ways, they're both very narrow. And are you saying that they're both using the wrong methods? I'm not sure why you call Laudermilk narrow. Well, I guess because he would use killing to achieve his aims. Well, again, I was dragged into that. I liked Loudermilk, and I would have been personally happy to make him just a nice old man. But logically, I couldn't see any way to keep that organization alive or to achieve a bane without killing anybody. I didn't like doing that. And I thought it did give a sort of moral ambiguity to the whole underground. But I would rather do that than paper over the problem. okay I understand in other words at the end of that novel when gosh I forget his name Arthur or something like that when he becomes part of the underground movement and he ends the novel admiring water milk then the reader is supposed to feel the same way in your estimation well in fact I think I ought to have provided a viewpoint character who would have had a little more doubts about what water milk was up to But it couldn't have been Arthur because he wasn't that sophisticated. Okay, in reference to both of those books and to some of your short stories, particularly some of your better known ones like Country of the Kind or Masks, I see a strain of pessimism in your work. Is that simply a counter to the romance and stereotypes you saw in science fiction? Or does that that I'm not a pessimistic person in my daily life. I hate the word optimistic, but I'm cheerful most of the time. And I have a lot of fun. I don't worry too much about disasters in the future. I certainly don't enjoy seeing people slip on banana peels. But I like irony and surprising people in some stories. that disliked very much the story that because everything is going to be rosy and vivid in a very implausible way and everybody lapsed it up. I don't know why. Okay. In Country of the Kind, maybe I'm seeing too much in that, but I caught maybe a little satire on humanitarianism, overdoing humanitarianism, for instance. No, I don't think that was what I was after. This came out of a remark in Hell's Pavement. Let me think. Actually, it was in Loudermilk's journal, and he talked about a dream he had had of the future they were going to achieve in which everybody would be psychically healthy. And there probably wouldn't be any art or any humor. and I think I picked that up from something in Robert Graves' novel Watch the Norquan Drive his future society was like that everyone was terrifically healthy mentally but there were no jokes nobody nobody laughed at jokes and let me think the art that art didn't come into grave but I just began to wonder Would there be any artistic creation in a world in which everybody was completely healthy mentally? Again, this is a proposition that seemed to be interesting to a floor. I wouldn't defend it necessarily. I think there's something to it, though. I think that art comes out of some kind of a pinch that you get in your childhood and that if you really had a healthy society there simply wouldn't be anything to make good art out of. Just recently I run across a reference to a painting of Picasso's which I'd never heard of before it's called War and Peace and it's in two parts on the left side you see war and there are all kinds of fascinating demons running around on the right side all I could think of for peace was a bunch of old men playing handpipes just quite well. And it just seemed to me that a completely healthy and peaceful world would be rather bloody hell. Okay. I imagine one of your better known stories is that humorous one, To Serve Man. I wondered if there was an impetus behind that one. You wondered if there was a witch? An impetus or a particular idea from which it originated? Oh, that came out of a remark by my second wife when she was pregnant with our first child. She was looking forward to the delivery and she imagined the doctor holding up the kid and flapping on the buttocks and herself saying give him one for me. And that became the last line of the story. No, not the last line but pretty close to it. Yeah, I remember now, I read that. Story ideas can come out of anywhere. Something somebody says, just a word or a phrase, or something you see in the grocery store. Sometimes, so trivial, you can't imagine where the story itself comes from, but it sort of accreets itself around almost any sharp object. One of your later books, I think the stories go back a ways, but one of the later published books that you've had, The World in Thorin. To me, it was, of course, very different than most of your other work. And I wondered why you decided to try your hand at fantasy. What makes you call it fantasy? I'm curious because a lot of people have thought that. Boy, I don't know what else to call it. Why wouldn't you call it science fiction? Well, okay, one of my questions was going to be, you provide some background there. For instance, I get the idea, if it's the earth, that it had been overheated and some scientists have had to move it and perhaps creatures went underground and formed these societies and caverns. I guess if that background were extrapolated or extended, it could be seen as science fiction. I guess I didn't make that plain enough. I thought I had, in the introductory sections of the chapters, I thought I had laid out more or less what happened the film was about to go Nova people made a spaceship out of the earth and propelled it out of the solar system and also went underground to accommodate the increasing population put the planet under the control of a central computer and then there was a war which destroyed civilization the complete control was turned over to computers and was directed to do whatever was necessary for the welfare of human beings. And since the computer had not been told what welfare meant to human beings, it had to try to figure out what was the best society. And therefore, having sealed up these caverns in order to prevent another war, it promoted the growth of different kinds of cultures. Each one in each little cavern. Hoping to find out eventually what the best one was. Hoping to pass. But that was the world in which the novel takes place in. I really thought I had indicated that sufficiently, but perhaps not. Well, you did near the end of the book, but I think maybe what threw me off in particular was the beginning of it, where you sort of present a Scandinavian-type society at the beginning, which immediately connoted to me in Middle Ages and medievalism and that kind of fantasy. Yes, I know, but there have been lots of science fiction stories. I think too many, in fact, written about the future world in which we've gone back to feudalism. Okay. A little earlier, you mentioned that when you were—I think you made a statement about fantasy. Did you say that fantasy could be deeper than science fiction? No, I didn't mean to say that. I was talking about Ed German's fantasy and science fiction. I think the quality of that magazine, although variable, that is the quality of the writing, has been a little higher than most science fiction magazines because of the presence of the fantasy writers. There's a long tradition of literacy, good writing, fantasy we haven't had in science fiction. Do you have a useful distinction that could distinguish science fiction and fantasy for me? Sure. Science fiction is a branch of fantasy. That's all it is. It's that branch which appeals which or let me start over which helps to create suspension of disbelief in the reader by appealing to the authority of science. It doesn't mean there's necessarily any science stories are usually in, but it throws up this cloud of authority by referring to something. And then you can relax and say, well, this is the thing that this could actually happen. Okay, I have about just two or three more questions. Can you handle that? Sure. Okay. What's your reaction to critics' response to your own work? well really i haven't had a whole lot of trouble with critics when i do get an unfavorable review i consider the source so i mean say well that turkey do you understand the book or whatever i've very seldom had to reply to a critic i think it's a mug game do so unless you can nail them to the wall with some factual error okay uh I got a hold of that volume that was, I think it was, Barry Maltzberg put it together, The Best of Dame and I, I think it was. Near the end of that book was that story down there, in which you remarked that hardly anybody had seen the purpose of that one. So I worked on it. Tell me what you saw. Okay. a society which is too sterile which has removed itself from its roots this man can write stories actually the computer writes the stories he just chooses certain things, buttons to push but he finds that he needs something which is more of a low-life, nitty-gritty real-life nature and he seeks it out in a sort of a clandestine way that's right and I think the only part that people didn't get because I really didn't want to say it was that sometime in the recent past there's been a race war and the black skinned people of this country have been wiped out and everybody else is carrying a terrific load of guilt there are no more Negroes in Maryland instead we've imported Abelichian people to fill the place if you look at the dialogue in the way they're referred to you see that they are Appalachian people little boys tucking into a platter of frozen greens and so on they're white but they're southern and he's attracted to this prostitute who appears in the last scene because she's so dark that she might almost be meanware okay, good could you tell me what kind of future work plans you have for your own fiction I'm staring down the last couple of chapters of a novel which is under contract with Berkeley called The Man in the Tree. I should have told you that the last one, The World of Thoroughin, is a book that I was hung up on for 15 years. I walked on it intermittently for all that time. I'd write a chapter and then I'd come to another stone wall and then it's back off. I finally got the thing finished and that's what's the block. Now I'm trying to write not with speed but it's possible I ever did. The reason the block I think was that I set myself as an impossible task. As you know, that novel is divided into episodes almost every one of which takes place in a new culture. I have to invent the culture and its history and customs and all that stuff. It was just absurdly difficult. weren't some of the episodes in that published separately as short stories that's why Fred Pohl ran, I think, three of them in Galaxy and you have to go pretty far back in the files to find them because this took me 15 years to finish them okay, listen, Mr. I could keep on asking questions for a long time but I think this is probably enough we've taken enough of your time listen, what we do is now we will edit these into shows our program is aired every day for five minutes so we'll probably get five or six shows out of this we're probably talking about maybe six weeks to two months into the future so when they're edited and done we'll send you copies okay, and listen one more question, do you think if we wrote in a few months your wife might consent to an interview also? I'm sure she'd love to okay, we might do that then and listen, we appreciate your time very much it's been a pleasure and keep up the work okay okay okay goodbye bye bye

segments.text: What I've done, Mr. Knight, is simply to, as I said, you've done so much.
You've been so involved in the field that it was hard to get a handle on how to approach this.
But what I've done is sort of divide up into different areas,
and I'll ask you some brief questions on each one.
And the first one would involve your entry into science fiction.
You came through the fan structure,
and I wondered if you could explain how you were introduced to that.
I sort of thought that might come up,
and I was rooting about it a little yesterday.
what if you asked me to where I would contribute my gigantic success?
I would have to say mostly luck.
I can trace my career back through a series of just astounding coincidences,
all the way back to Hulu Gernsback.
And I can demonstrate that at each of these points,
If something rather unlikely had not happened, I wouldn't be doing what I'm doing.
For instance, if Hugo Gernsback had not come to this country from Luxembourg when he was
14 and started a magazine called Amazing Stories in 1926, you'll see as I go on that none of
the other things could have happened.
So here I am, a 13-year-old kid in Hood River, Oregon, reading science fiction magazines,
I found out about the fanzines
and rode away for a few
and this way got into correspondence
I was trying to write some stories
and I sent a couple to Lowndes,
as a sort of half-assed literary agent.
And all these things added up together
got an offer from a publisher
to edit a new science fiction magazine.
He had no budget, whatever, for stories.
And he knew about me from Lowndes.
to the first issue of Superstirring Science Story?
And of course I said yes.
I would have paid for the privilege.
And as a consequence of that,
the Futurians invited me to come and be a Futurian,
live in one of their communal dwellings in New York
even as far as we've gone.
And I lived there a couple of years
Again, it was Fred Pulle, got me a job at popular publications where he was working.
I needed an assistant editor, and he knew I would work cheap.
So he got me an interview where I got the job.
Spent about a year there, and I'm perfectly convinced now, looking back,
that it was that training at popular publications that enabled me to write fiction professionally.
It was a training that you couldn't get in any school.
How did you get it now?
But it just kind of soaked in because I was reading the slush pile, the unsolicited manuscripts,
and it became perfectly obvious after a while what the difference was between the stuff
we were rejecting and the stuff we were printing.
So when I quit that job, I started writing and went on from there.
I did another stint later at Popular, 1949.
And I also worked for a while at the Scott Merritt's Literary Agency, which was a reading
fee agency, where we would get
these awful manuscripts and have to criticize them.
I think that helped me a good deal, too.
for young writers, I would certainly
that those pulp magazines don't exist anymore.
You can possibly get an editorial job or anything
a terrible job in the reading
Okay, we talked to Frederick Pohl some time ago
and he told us a little about the Futurians
and of course you've written a book on that too
Could you be a little more specific, sort of briefly
what your relationship with the Futurians was
Well, the Futurians were a very informal organization
who were trying to become professional
and in some cases had a little bit of impact
At that time in New York,
There were lots of apartments among them that were very cheap.
I think the rental might have been about 30 bucks for a four-bedroom railroad flat.
If you had four people living there, it was quite cheap.
And we divided up the household duties around with the cooking.
And I did the fish washing, which I hated.
We really didn't have any money at all.
and we bought the cheapest wine we could find,
which was something like 85 cents a gallon.
Our major entertainment was walking down
and looking at the bright lights
and having a cup of coffee in the cafeteria
The first stuff I did for fanzines was not critical in the usual sense.
I mean, it wasn't book-reviewed or that kind of thing, but it was parody mostly.
The things that I thought were really outstandingly dumb in the magazine, funny enough to parody,
and I did a lot of that.
But when I say a lot, I lie, because I only published two issues of my fanzines
and did very little for other magazines.
I did a long critical essay
for one of Larry Shaw's amateur magazines.
That was really the first critical work
in the usual chemical I did.
From what I've read of your,
say, your collected essays and so forth,
has been to deal with the question
of science fiction as a higher,
to raise its literary standards perhaps,
to make it something more than
just a kind of a second class
And I wondered if you thought
that science fiction could ever compete
or is it too limited to do that?
And I didn't see any reason why science fiction shouldn't be
as good as any other kind of fiction can be.
I don't think now that it ever has been.
And I still have, and I have a few doubts now about whether it can be.
But at that time, as you say,
my effort was to try to raise the standards, improve the breed,
by lifting it out of the Pope formulas.
H.L. Gould was responsible for part of that
and Tony Boucher for another part,
and it really seemed to me that we were on a plateau
which could quite well be succeeded by another plateau
And I think that was what I was pushing for.
We have some very good work being done,
But it doesn't seem to me that the field as a whole
has advanced as much as I expected it would beyond the 1950s.
Would you see any big changes in the field since you began?
and picked up all the back issues I could find
By that time, Gernsback had lost his magazines,
and he didn't have Gernsback in SF anymore.
His idea was to teach science through science fiction.
He didn't always do it, but that was his ideal.
And then you had his successor at Amazing Stories,
Tio Connor Sloan, who was then in his 80s.
And he really did not have
In fact, he said in print
and more or less transformed it
he raised the level in a certain direction
or at least a semblance of it
he wanted plausible stories about the future
a brave hero and his jodhors
and also because he got a,
so on until there would be no distinguishable difference in terms of quality between science
And as I say, I don't think that happens.
Some of those quantum leaps in the past that you've mentioned have been due, I think, to,
as you said, to some of the more influential editors.
Do we have editors today who still have that kind of influence?
Well, I think we have certainly influential editors, but I don't think they're trying
I think they're trying to produce what they conceive the reading public wants and they're
George Sithers, for example, is a very sharp editor.
And Stanley Schmidt, I think, is doing an excellent job with analog.
And of course Ed Furman has been working along with fantasy and science fiction for many
Publishing a lot of really neat stuff.
Fantasy and science fiction has always had a more literary cast.
partly because it's about half and half
the literary quality of fantasy writing
when you began your Orbit anthologies in 1966,
what kind of hopes did you have for them?
What was your idea behind them?
I just thought there was a marketing strategy there that hadn't been explored.
It seemed to me that with hardcover publication,
if you could get book club and paperback,
you'd have a basis on which you could pay very good rates and get a broad audience.
and that because it was hardcover,
originally you wouldn't have to worry about
Orbit never did achieve the sales
It got a few book club
It wasn't every issue, it should have been.
So after they went to harbor with the series,
they couldn't get paperback at all,
and that was what made them cancel it after a while.
They hung on quite a long time.
They were very decent about it.
But eventually they saw that this wasn't going to happen.
Well, was that the first anthology of original science fiction
Fred Poole had done a series called Star.
It must have been in the late 50s.
and before him there had been
who the editors were, let me think
the first one actually goes back quite a way
but Fred was the first series of
anthologies of original science fiction stories
I guess the literary level of
the orbit series, so you must be proud of that
through some of those years, that I think the majority of the
Nebula Award stories came from orbit, didn't they?
For a couple of years, it was
scoring heavily in the nebulas, yeah.
But I don't really know whether that
has anything to do with the quality of the stories,
or just because I was conspicuous at the time,
I was the president of SFWA.
onto the next area I want to talk about.
You had a large part in the founding of that.
Could you explain your part in that
and why you were interested in starting it?
Well, about ten years earlier, it must have been,
there was an effort to form a guild of science fiction writers,
and I went to one or two of their meetings,
and it was pitiful because they used the parliamentary procedure
and they had 50 people all arguing,
and they finally hammered out a set of bylaws
and elected officers, and then nothing happened.
The officers all went home and died.
And I realized at that time that there was a very easy way to do it.
You didn't have to have the big meetings, and you didn't have to have all that apparatus.
But I didn't think I was conspicuous enough at that time.
I didn't think anybody knew who I was.
Later on, I was becoming more visible, and I realized that I probably could do it.
by receiving in the same week
for flat fees, which I thought was
So I wrote a flyer, the one-page
authors not to sign agreements for
if you'd like more information of this kind, send in your
three bucks and become a charter member of SFWA.
So I got a flock of responses.
When I had about 78, I declared them the charter members
and wrote a set of bylaws and sent that around,
and we were more or less in business.
Okay, and what did you serve?
One or two years as president?
Okay, and you'd have to look back.
Wouldn't you have to judge it today as a successful organization?
I think it's done more for members
than any other writer's organization that I know of.
for Tolkien and lots of things for
isn't that awful, her name just popped out of my head.
we've settled a lot of grievances.
every right conceivably attached to a story,
and we made such a stench that they withdrew it.
About a year ago, we talked to Norman Spinrad, I guess, who's the current president,
and he said he was interested in working on internationalizing
or hooking up with some of the European organizations.
Do you think that's a good idea?
There's a lot of feeling among the members that we ought to be more international than we are.
I always resisted that because it didn't seem to me
that we could work effectively for writers living abroad
and not publishing in this country.
I don't see that it could do us any damage.
Okay, let me move on to one more area
before I get down to just a few questions on your own work.
I guess you realize I'll probably have to ask something
about the Milford Science Fiction Writers Conference.
Could you also give me a brief statement
Well, this was in the mid-50s,
which is a very small town
It was sort of the way
building a boat in the basement,
and nothing was done about this
until Judy and I went to the
much more better than we realized.
and we thought that possibly if we invited
people to the military, they could actually
And we sent out the invitation. We got
Jim Wish to join the masthead,
and this was the year in which
so it was easier for people to get out there
We had evening discussions that went on for several hours
with people raising parts of hands to do the next to speak.
So we decided to do it annually.
we didn't have a World Con near us to provide all that many people.
and the attendance dropped to, I don't know, 15 or so.
When it gradually came up again,
we began to get a bunch of regulars who came every year
and then there'd be a few more and so on.
So in the later years, we got up to about 25 or 30,
which was really as much as we could handle in the workshops,
which by then had become a regular feature of Milford,
where everybody would submit a manuscript or two.
And then every morning we'd all sit around
and discuss them in turn around the surface.
This is probably an obvious question,
but I want to ask it anyhow to see your response.
what kind of benefit would writers get from that?
which is an outgrowth of Milford.
You have to have a control group
People point out what it was in your story
that you absolutely haven't seen, sometimes crucially.
And, again, just from my own experience,
it seems to me that learning to criticize other people's stories technically
enables you eventually to criticize your own,
which is a difficult thing at all.
It becomes a little bit easier to see the flaws in your own.
you're not associated with the Milford
no, we had to stop doing it
don't hold me to the number because I'm very
it turned out that year that we
had signed up for so many things
in the summer that were going to have to drop something
so we had to stop doing Milford
So that Milford, as it has turned out,
has become sort of a duplication for us
of what we were doing at Clarion.
Ed Bryan has done it a couple of times,
about every year, in Denver or thereabouts.
And it is still going on.
But the difference between the two,
like you said, the Clarion would be more
where you would be the teacher
Okay, let me just move on
they used to do that a lot
I'm sure you've gotten questions on this
in fact I know you have
at least I as a reader

to become sort of a good guy

why did you choose to have him
I wanted to do a realistic ending.
I thought that the happy ending
And this was one of the things
that's interesting in writing the novel
that you put into that novel,
it's kind of ironic that a device like that
which can give people whatever they want
would lead to a slave master society
do you think that's the way it would work
or would you be being deliberately pessimistic?
well, I thought it was logical
I was counter-punching in that novel
against some other treatments of the same device
the same gadgets that had been published before
of course chaos ensued, and he
rescued the world by inventing a kind of
And that was one too many
rabbits out of the hat, I thought.
again, I just wanted to do it
realistically. It seemed to me that
if I had made a good case
that, in fact, slavery would be the
No, I admit that it was an imaginative projection.
I don't necessarily defend the idea that that's what would happen in practice.
And another writer, several years later, I'll think of his name if I possibly can,
wrote a story in response to that one, which really delighted me.
I like this dialogue aspect of science fiction,
in which he showed that a good marketer,
even if there was a matter duplicative.
When A for Anything and Analog Men,
when those were published in the 50s,
there wasn't much critical science fiction.
We are criticizing a consumer-oriented society.
There wasn't much of that those days, was there?
No, I think Fred Gould and Ezele Cure was the space merchant's gravy planet,
it was called and it was published in the magazine,
was a stunning rejection of the kind of dramatic cliché
that has been dominant in science fiction up to a new time.
There had been social satire in science fiction
for a long time before, during science fiction.
And the magazine published some of it,
It didn't have the cutting edge that gravy plan it had.
Okay, maybe just one question on Analog Man.
I think that you're contrasting the scientist,
Cusco or Cusco, whatever his name is,
I liked Loudermilk, and I would have been personally happy to make him just a nice old man.
But logically, I couldn't see any way to keep that organization alive
or to achieve a bane without killing anybody.
And I thought it did give a sort of moral ambiguity to the whole underground.
But I would rather do that than paper over the problem.
at the end of that novel
that I'm not a pessimistic person
but I'm cheerful most of the time.
And I have a lot of fun.
seeing people slip on banana peels.
that disliked very much the story
that because everything is going to be rosy
and vivid in a very implausible way
maybe I'm seeing too much in that,
but I caught maybe a little satire
No, I don't think that was what I was after.
This came out of a remark in Hell's Pavement.
Actually, it was in Loudermilk's journal,
and he talked about a dream he had had of the future they were going to achieve
in which everybody would be psychically healthy.
And there probably wouldn't be any art or any humor.
Would there be any artistic creation
in a world in which everybody
this is a proposition that seemed to be
I think there's something to it, though.
comes out of some kind of a pinch
that you get in your childhood
which I'd never heard of before
And it just seemed to me that a completely healthy and peaceful world
I imagine one of your better known stories
is that humorous one, To Serve Man.
I wondered if there was an impetus behind that one.
Yeah, I remember now, I read that.
Story ideas can come out of anywhere.
Something somebody says, just a word or a phrase,
or something you see in the grocery store.
Sometimes, so trivial, you can't imagine where the story itself comes from,
but it sort of accreets itself around almost any sharp object.
One of your later books, I think the stories go back a ways,
but one of the later published books that you've had, The World in Thorin.
To me, it was, of course, very different than most of your other work.
And I wondered why you decided to try your hand at fantasy.
What makes you call it fantasy?
I'm curious because a lot of people have thought that.
Boy, I don't know what else to call it.
Why wouldn't you call it science fiction?
Well, okay, one of my questions was going to be,
For instance, I get the idea, if it's the earth,
that it had been overheated and some scientists
have had to move it and perhaps creatures went underground
and formed these societies and caverns.
I guess if that background were extrapolated or extended,
it could be seen as science fiction.
I guess I didn't make that plain enough.
I thought I had, in the introductory sections of the chapters,
I thought I had laid out more or less what happened
the film was about to go
a spaceship out of the earth
and propelled it out of the solar system
planet under the control of a central computer
and then there was a war
the complete control was turned over to computers
and was directed to do whatever was necessary
for the welfare of human beings.
And since the computer had not been told
what welfare meant to human beings,
it had to try to figure out what was the best society.
And therefore, having sealed up these caverns in order to prevent another war,
it promoted the growth of different kinds of cultures.
Each one in each little cavern.
Hoping to find out eventually what the best one was.
But that was the world in which the novel takes place in.
I really thought I had indicated that sufficiently, but perhaps not.
Well, you did near the end of the book,
but I think maybe what threw me off in particular was the beginning of it,
where you sort of present a Scandinavian-type society at the beginning,
which immediately connoted to me in Middle Ages and medievalism and that kind of fantasy.
Yes, I know, but there have been lots of science fiction stories.
I think too many, in fact, written about the future world in which we've gone back to feudalism.
A little earlier, you mentioned that when you were—I think you made a statement about fantasy.
Did you say that fantasy could be deeper than science fiction?
No, I didn't mean to say that.
I was talking about Ed German's fantasy and science fiction.
I think the quality of that magazine, although variable,
that is the quality of the writing,
has been a little higher than most science fiction magazines
because of the presence of the fantasy writers.
There's a long tradition of literacy, good writing,
fantasy we haven't had in science fiction.
Do you have a useful distinction
Science fiction is a branch of fantasy.
by appealing to the authority of science.
It doesn't mean there's necessarily any science
stories are usually in, but it throws up this cloud of authority by referring to something.
And then you can relax and say, well, this is the thing that this could actually happen.
Okay, I have about just two or three more questions. Can you handle that?
Okay. What's your reaction to critics' response to your own work?
